case_name: Bashiruddin Ashraf v. Bihar Subai Sunni Majlis-e-Awqaf

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 739 of 1963 is an appeal from the judgment and decree order dated December 1960 of the Patna High Court in Misc. Appeals Nos. 688 of 1958 of 1959 and Civil Revision No. 1153 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 739 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and decree order dated December 1960 of the Patna High Court in Misc. Appeals Nos. 688 of 1958 of 1959 and Civil Revision No. 1153 of 1958.

facts.text: The appellant Bashiruddin Ashraf was Mutwalli of certain Waqf properties in Monghyr District dedicated by one Sheikh Golam Yahya by a registered Waqfnama dated April 11, 1870.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Bashiruddin Ashraf was Mutwalli of certain Waqf properties in Monghyr District, dedicated by one Sheikh Golam Yahya by a registered Waqfnama dated April 11, 1870.

facts.text: Under the Waqfnama Mutwallis were chosen from the descendants in the male line of the Waqif from generation to generation.

anchor.surface_text: Under this deed Mutwallis were chosen from the descendants in the male line of the Waqif from generation to generation.

facts.text: The first Mutwalli was the Waqif.

anchor.surface_text: The first Mutwalli was the Waqif.

facts.text: After the Waqif's death his wife held charge of the Toliat.

anchor.surface_text: After his death, his wife held charge of the Toliat.

facts.text: After her death the appellant's father and from 1930 the appellant were Mutwallis.

anchor.surface_text: After her death the appellants father and from 1930 the appellant were Mutwallis.

facts.text: The Mutwalli in-charge was entitled to 9/48th share of the income as his remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: The Mutwalli in-charge was entitled to 9/48th share of the income as his remuneration.

facts.text: On April 1, 1948 the Bihar Waqfs Act, 1947 (Act 8 of 1948) came into force and this Waqf was registered as Waqf No. 67.

anchor.surface_text: On April 1, 1948, the Bihar Waqfs Act, 1947  Act 8 of 1948  came into force and this Waqf came under the purview of that Act and was registered as Waqf No. 67.

facts.text: The Bihar Subai Sunni Majlis-e-Awqaf (Majlis) began supervising this Waqf.

anchor.surface_text: Under the scheme of the Act the Bihar Subai Sunni Majlis-e-Awqaf  shortly Majlis  began supervising this Waqf.

facts.text: Syed Bashiruddin was the Sadr (Chairman) of the Majlis at all material times.

anchor.surface_text: At all material times one Syed Bashiruddin was the Sadr  Chairman  of the Majlis

facts.text: Syed Mehdi Hassan was the Nazir-e-Awqaf under S. 22.

anchor.surface_text: and Syed Mehdi Hassan was the Nazir-e-Awqaf under S. 22.

facts.text: On March 2, 1949 Syed Naziruddin Ashraf (step-brother of the appellant) and some others presented an application for removal of the appellant from Mutwalliship on numerous charges including mismanagement, misappropriation, wanton waste and dissipation of Waqf property, falsification of accounts, etc.

anchor.surface_text: On March 2, 1949 Syed Naziruddin Ashraf  step-brother of the appellant  and some others presented an application for removal of the appellant from Mutwalliship on. numerous charges, including mismanagement, misappropriation, wanton waste and dissipation of Waqf property, falsification of accounts, etc.

facts.text: The application was registered as Case No. 37 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: This was registered as Case No. 37 of 1949.

facts.text: Mehadi Hassan made an enquiry and reported on May 25, 1950 to the Majlis that the charges against the appellant were proved.

anchor.surface_text: An enquiry was made by Mehadi Hassan, who reported on May 25, 1950 to the Majlis that the charges levelled against the appellant were proved.

facts.text: Majlis considered the report at its meeting on August 20, 1950 and issued notice to the appellant to show cause why he should be removed.

anchor.surface_text: His report was companysidered by the Majlis at its meeting dated August 20, 1950 and a numberice was issued to the appellant to show cause why he should number be removed.

facts.text: The appellant showed cause.

anchor.surface_text: He showed cause.

facts.text: The Nazir submitted a second report on October 15, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Nazir was directed to submit a second report which he did on October 15, 1950.

facts.text: The appellant was examined.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was then examined

facts.text: On November 28, 1950 the Sadr passed an order agreeing with the Nazir's report and confirming findings of mismanagement etc.

anchor.surface_text: and on November 28, 1950 the Sadr passed an order agreeing with the report of the Nazir and companyfirming the findings given by the Nazir regarding mis-management etc.

facts.text: An auditor reported on February 8, 1951 that Rs. 9682/1/3 was due from the appellant to the Waqf estate.

anchor.surface_text: An auditor was appointed to check the accounts and he reported on February 8, 1951 that a sum of Rs. 9682/1/3 was due from the appellant to the Waqf estate.

facts.text: The Sadr ordered the appellant to deposit the amount on or before April 2, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Sadr ordered the appellant to deposit this amount in a recognised bank on or before April 2, 1951.

facts.text: The appellant failed to deposit the amount.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellant failed to deposit the amount,

facts.text: On June 28, 1951 the Sadr passed an order removing the appellant from office and appointing Maulvi Mohammad Shoeb as Mutwalli for one year under s.32.

anchor.surface_text: the Sadr passed an order on June 28, 1951 removing him from the office and appointed in his place a pleader  Maulvi Mohammad Shoeb  as Mutwalli for a period of one year under s. 32 of the Act

facts.text: The appellant made an application to the District Judge under s.27(3) registered as Miscellaneous Case No. 30/4 of 1951 to set aside the Sadr's order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then made an application to the District Judge under s. 27 3  of the Bihar Waqfs Act for setting aside the order of the Sadr and the proceedings were registered as Miscellaneous Case No. 30/4 of 1951.

facts.text: The Additional District Judge, Monghyr decided all issues except the 3rd against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional District Judge, Monghyr decided all the issue. except the 3rd, against the appellant.

facts.text: The order appointing Maulvi Mohammad Shoeb was held without jurisdiction and vacated.

anchor.surface_text: The order appointing the temporary Mutwalli questioned in the third issue was held to be without jurisdiction on the ground that it had to be ratified by the District Judge under s. 32 and the appointment was vacated.

facts.text: Patna High Court by judgment dated December 21, 1960 dismissed the appellant's appeal and accepted Maulvi Md. Shoeb's appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by a companymon judgment delivered on December 21, 1960, dismissed the appeal of the appellant and accepted that of Maulvi Md. Shoeb.

facts.text: Bihar Waqfs Amendment Act, 1951 (Bihar Act 18 of 1951) received assent on May 24, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The italicised words were inserted by s. 2 of the Bihar Waqfs  Amendment  Act, 1951  Bihar Act 18 of 1951  from May 24, 1951 on which date the amending Act received the assent of the Governor of Bihar.

facts.text: In Bashiruddin Ashraf v. State of Bihar this Court held s.58 of the Bihar Waqfs Act valid.

anchor.surface_text: This Court by its judgment in Bashiruddin Ashraf v. State of Bihar .  held the section to be valid.

facts.text: The charges against the appellant were held proved by the Nazir, Sadr, Additional District Judge and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The truth of the allegations against the appellant was investigated by the Nazir and the charges were held proved. The report of the Nazir was accepted by the Sadr, the Additional District Judge and the High Court.

issues.text: Whether the Majlis or the Sadr was competent and had jurisdiction to direct the Mutwalli to produce the accounts of the Waqf estate, hold enquiries and pass orders on the basis of such enquiries for a period prior to the enforcement of the Act?

issues.text: Whether the powers of removal conferred on the Majlis could be exercised by the Sadr when the matter was already before the Majlis under sections 37 and 38?

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was contended that the powers of removal conferred on the Majlis could not be exercised by the Sadr when the matter was already before the Majlis. Sections 37 and 38 provide Exercise by Sadr of powers of Majlis.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate raised the contention before us that a number of his arguments on facts brought to the notice of the Honble Judges were number considered

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s fundamental rights. Though he raised the questions of his fundamental rights the provisions of the Waqfs Act are so manifestly in the public interes

arguments.court_reasoning: Deprecates practice; judgment comprehensive; no enquiry into High Court omissions without proof; finality on facts

holdings.text: Section 32 of the Bihar Waqfs Act confers jurisdiction on the Majlis to appoint a temporary Mutwalli without requiring prior permission or subsequent ratification by a competent court; the appointment endures until a contrary order by a competent court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly pointed out that those words denoted that the appointment was to endure according to its tenor till an order to the contrary was passed by a competent court. This conclusion is so patently correct that we need say nothing more than this. On merits of the removal of the appellant the High Court endorsed the view of the Additional District Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'subject to any order by the competent court' means the appointment stands until overturned, not requiring assent; High Court view patently correct.

holdings.text: The amendment to s.27(2)(h) by Bihar Waqfs Amendment Act, 1951 confers jurisdiction prospectively on Majlis but the power to remove Mutwalli for disobedience can be exercised regarding orders/directions issued and disobeyed before the amendment.

anchor.surface_text: The amendment, no doubt, conferred jurisdiction upon the Majlis to act prospectively from the date of the amendment but the power under the amendment could be exercised in respect of orders and directions issued by the Majlis and disobeyed by the Mutwalli before the amendment came into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prospective jurisdiction but applies to anterior conduct without retrospectivity if no vested right disturbed; otherwise no remedy for past misconduct post-amendment.

holdings.text: There is no vested right to continue as Mutwalli after mismanagement and misconduct are established.

anchor.surface_text: It would be another matter if there was a vested right which was taken away but there could be no vested right to continue as Mutwalli after mismanagement and misconduct of many sorts were established.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act contemplates removal for such conduct; no protected interest in office post-misconduct.

holdings.text: Orders and directions differ only in degree; disobedience of either merits removal of Mutwalli.

anchor.surface_text: Orders and directions express the binding wish of the Majlis and the two words only differ in degree. An order is more peremptory than a direction and an argument can never be right which suggests that while disobedience of a direction should merit the punishment of removal, disobedience of an order should go unpunished.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-amendment s.47 covered both; distinction untenable as order is stronger form.

holdings.text: Sections 27 and 32 of the Bihar Waqfs Act are not ultra vires the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: These cannot be said to be unconstitutional in any way and the action has thus been placed before us as falling outside these sections or not supported by them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior upholding of s.58; provisions in public interest; confined attack rejected.

holdings.text: Sadr can exercise Majlis powers of removal under ss.37 and 38 in emergency or by delegation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.37 allows immediate action if meeting untimely; reported to Majlis; s.38 delegation possible; approved by Majlis.

holdings.text: Supreme Court will not re-examine factual findings accepted by lower courts including High Court unless omission admitted or proved.

anchor.surface_text: The truth of the allegations against the appellant was investigated by the Nazir and the charges were held proved. The report of the Nazir was accepted by the Sadr, the Additional District Judge and the High Court... This Court will ordinarily regard the details of the argument given in the judgment of the High Court as correct and will not enter upon an enquiry as to what was or was not argued there.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fair trial had; finality on facts; deprecates alleging omissions without proof.

edges.explanation: h1 holding on s.32 jurisdiction for appointment addresses i3

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly pointed out that those words denoted that the appointment was to endure according to its tenor till an order to the contrary was passed by a competent court. This conclusion is so patently correct that we need say nothing more than this. On merits of the removal of the appellant the High Court endorsed the view of the Additional District Judge.
The appeal is devoid of merit.

The amendment, no doubt, conferred jurisdiction upon the Majlis to act prospectively from the date of the amendment but the power under the amendment could be exercised in respect of orders and directions issued by the Majlis and disobeyed by the Mutwalli before the amendment came into force.
The appeal is devoid of merit.

It would be another matter if there was a vested right which was taken away but there could be no vested right to continue as Mutwalli after mismanagement and misconduct of many sorts were established.
The appeal is devoid of merit.

Orders and directions express the binding wish of the Majlis and the two words only differ in degree. An order is more peremptory than a direction and an argument can never be right which suggests that while disobedience of a direction should merit the punishment of removal, disobedience of an order should go unpunished.
The appeal is devoid of merit.

The appeal is devoid of merit.
